bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, April 3, 1880

div1.p: Reed describes his departure from Arizona, and the confusion in getting his next permanent assignment. He awaits McPherson's visit.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, April 3, 1880
div1.opener:
Baltimore, Md
April 3rd, 1880,
“THE CARROLLTON,”
Baltimore, Light & German Sts.
BALTIMORE, MD.
F. W. COLEMAN,
MANAGER. My dear Dorsey:
div1.p:
I have re-
-ceived both of your epistles-
am charmed that, for once
in my erratic life, I should
have smitten the “spike upon
the larger end,” so to speak, in
the matter of your address.
I will, as promised, nar-
-rate very briefly the causes
& consequences of the past month-
Know then, my dear Pillula, that
the order for the abandonment
of my former trysting place
went into effect February
24th, On which date, having
snugly packed all my bag-
-gage away, I left Oswego
with Battery “I” 2nd Artillery,
en route to Fort McHenry,
where we arrived, next day,
Feb. 25th. I was under orders
to accompany the Batt. to McHenry,
& there await further orders-
on the 27th I went with my
family to Norfolk, Va & returned
on the 2nd March, leaving them
in Norfolk- Thereafter I basked
in the fog, so to speak, at McHen-
ry, & awaited my orders with
the greatest impatience-
About the 15th, the medical
Director sent me a private
letter, telling me that I would
go to Fort Columbus, N.Y.,
whereupon my heart gave
one mighty leap, & “stocks”
went up tremendously- I
even imagined myself gazing,
with much complacency,
at “Cleopatra's needle”, &
other objects of interest about
“York”, when along came
another private note, from
the same source, which said
that my services would not
be needed at Columbus-
Ha! ha! then I arose, with
fiendish glee, & much desired
to remove the scalp from
that aged M.D.! Howbeit
my dear Dorsey, the Gods
had not altogether deserted
me, for on the 24th, I was
assigned to permanent duty
at McHenry, which suited
me to a dot, & was certainly
several “pegs” higher than
I had ever aspired- I am
now only awaiting my
baggage from Ontario's
classic shore. I think that
that by April 9th I will be
in my house -- at least, I must
hope it- My wife, boy, & the
“wild Susan” have been with
me here just two weeks, to-day.
“Roosting” at this “Ranch”, Dor-
sey, I find very comfortable-
the “grub” strikes “the spot,” every
time. Beans & breakfast-bacon
excellent! Ha! ha! “ Oh carry me
back to” Arizona! Do you really
expect to come over to Baltimore?
I should be charmed to see you!
I only wish that you would
come over after we get
all settled in our house,
& then I would do the “Correct-
thing! Adios -- write at once--
Mrs. R. joins me in kind regards to
Mrs. McP. & yourself-
div1.closer:
Ever, your sincere
friend, “Bolus.” formerly of Ariz-
